name: NPR
text:
President Trump's call for his supporters "to go into the polls and watch very carefully" — along with his baseless claims that Democrats will "steal" the election — have raised fears about potential polling place confrontations. 
https://t.co/tLTszhdvg2

name: NPR
text:
RT @npratc: The president used Tuesday's debate — his largest platform so far this election season — to try and undermine voters' confidence in the democratic process. Today on #NPRConsiderThis, we look at who else is trying to do that.
https://t.co/n4ltXRqAdv

name: NPR
text:
NEW: Brad Parscale, the former campaign manager and longtime digital strategist to President Trump, has stepped away from his role in the president's re-election effort.
https://t.co/QNBelorieS

name: NPR
text:
Mac Davis — a songwriter and performer who penned works for Dolly Parton, Elvis, Kenny Rogers and others — died on Tuesday in Nashville following heart surgery. He was 78.
https://t.co/4DH7odNPVV

name: NPR
text:
President Trump has consistently told Americans "the complete opposite" of what his health experts have been telling him in private meetings about COVID-19, according to Olivia Troye, a former Pence staffer.
https://t.co/Gj73H9nQ0d

name: NPR
text:
The wind-fueled flames of the Glass Fire have engulfed nearly 50,000 acres of land. "This isn't our first rodeo experiencing this," says the mayor of Santa Rosa, where more than 8,000 residents have evacuated.
https://t.co/UC2aeJcLwm

name: NPR
text:
The coronavirus crisis is squeezing families with children.

60% of households with kids have lost jobs, or businesses, or have had wages cut during the pandemic, a new NPR poll finds.

And experts say that could have lasting impacts on children.
https://t.co/bSTQ8Qb8b8

name: NPR
text:
Alabama Gov. Kay Ivey has apologized to Sarah Collins Rudolph, the survivor of the 1963 KKK bombing of a Birmingham church, whose lawyers assert the attack was "motivated" by the racist rhetoric of past state leaders.
https://t.co/HmqUddHmtl

name: NPR
text:
We want to hear from you: What does the American flag mean to you right now? Have those feelings changed over time?

Fill out the form linked below, and an NPR producer may be in touch for an upcoming story.
https://t.co/4F7kboUIV9

name: NPR
text:
A man has been charged with attempted murder after he fired multiple shots into a LA sheriff's patrol vehicle earlier this month. The gunman faces a maximum sentence of life in prison.
https://t.co/yh3F1fAP3o

name: NPR
text:
The head of the FAA conducted his own test flight of a Boeing 737 Max, saying "it responded well" — a major step in the agency's review of design and software changes made after 2 deadly crashes.
https://t.co/aVzpkcDHq5

name: NPR
text:
Amy Coney Barrett, Trump's Supreme Court nominee, says she was contacted by the White House about the job a day after the death of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.

Here are more insights from her Senate questionnaire:
https://t.co/MgYPRPbglf

name: NPR
text:
President Trump declined to denounce white supremacy during Tuesday's debate, commenting at one point, "Proud Boys, stand back and stand by."

@hereandnow looks at the Proud Boys and why many condemn the group. https://t.co/z1Z8NkaPUX

name: NPR
text:
Amy Coney Barrett, Trump's Supreme Court nominee, did not say she would recuse herself from cases related to the outcome of November's presidential election in paperwork filed for the confirmation process.
https://t.co/zfFf9gW9XZ

name: NPR
text:
After 57 years and multiple pleas for an apology and compensation, Alabama Gov. Kay Ivey apologized to Sarah Collins Rudolph, the survivor of the 1963 KKK bombing of a Birmingham church — but didn't commit to financial restitution.
https://t.co/6Fr61bQhnp

name: NPR
text:
Asked to compose music to put her thoughts into words in 2020, Tank and the Bangas singer Tarriona Ball responded with a new song, "Feelings." 

She says it came out of a need to process the pandemic and Black Lives Matter protests unfolding all at once.
https://t.co/TbV6YOscvN

name: NPR
text:
A group of “wellness” doctors, including one connected to the brand Goop, have promoted injections of an unproven and non-FDA-approved drug to treat COVID-19.

Experts say that could put patients at risk. 
https://t.co/lMlb6eddkW

name: NPR
text:
An heiress to the Seagram's liquor fortune has been sentenced to nearly 7 years in prison for fraud and forced labor as a leading member of Nxivm — a cult-like group accused of holding women captive and coercing them into sex with the group's leader.
https://t.co/RhAOqyuY0V

name: NPR
text:
Bobby Shmurda. Nipsey Hussle. Mac Phipps. DJ Drama. 
 
You’ve heard their names. But @LouderThanARiot goes deeper than headlines and trending topics. 
 
What do their stories tell us about America’s obsession with race and criminality? Starting Oct 8th: https://t.co/9UMkAMmjk0 https://t.co/IfLcV7QBpY

name: NPR
text: Robert E. Murray, the former CEO and president of the now-bankrupt Murray Energy, who fought against black lung regulations as a coal operator, has filed for black lung benefits. https://t.co/U7CcZoyd1v (@wvpublic)

name: NPR
text: With all the major races canceled this year, more athletes are measuring themselves against the clock, attempting to set what are known as Fastest Known Times. This year, nearly 3,000 new FKTs have been set. https://t.co/2yeAxfpZmD

name: NPR
text:
Since the 1970s, only two Supreme Court justices have been confirmed as quickly as Republicans are hoping to confirm Amy Coney Barrett.
https://t.co/H5OV3fJ6qz

name: NPR
text:
The CDC has extended a ban on cruises from U.S. ports until Oct. 31. 

Multiple outlets report that CDC director Robert Redfield wanted to extend the "no sail" order to next February — but was overruled by the White House.
https://t.co/K51jtMkDCv

name: NPR
text: Some public health experts hope the growing availability of faster, cheaper tests could lead to a new strategy of widespread testing — one that could finally get the pandemic under control. https://t.co/dUmaEMjPGW

name: NPR
text:
Despite people's fears, sophisticated "deepfakes" haven't arrived this political season. But it isn't because they aren't a threat, sources tell NPR. 

It's because simple deceptions — like selective editing or outright lies — have worked just fine.
https://t.co/j1ptuLskJv

name: NPR
text: Have you been prescribed thymosin alpha-1? If so, we'd like to hear from you. Reach out to @TomDreisbach with your story.

name: NPR
text:
A federal judge has ruled that the Trump administration's law enforcement commission must cease its work for now — saying the panel violated standing legal requirements by snubbing defense attorneys and community activists.
https://t.co/zJyOZMKzYB

name: NPR
text: All Songs Considered selects their favorite music released in September 2020, featuring Cuban hip-hop artist La Dame Blanche, Masego's summer wanderlust, and Big Thief's Adrianne Lenker and a reimagined mass. https://t.co/cjlzKPzZH9
